module: CSK-5 Module 4: Good Faith, Enforcement & Civil Procedure

questions.question: What does Germany’s §242 BGB ask a person who owes a duty to do?

options.A: Claims that follow only the literal contract wording even if it harms the other side.
options.B: Claims that deliver what they promised in a fair way that respects everyday practice and the other person’s interests.
options.C: Claims that ignore local custom and do the bare minimum.
options.D: Claims that wait for a court order before acting on any promise.

A.explanation: Option B is incorrect because §242 BGB exists precisely to stop parties hiding behind harsh literal wording when that would injure the counterparty.

B.explanation: Correct option A: §242 BGB, the German good-faith clause, obliges the debtor to perform as promised in a way that respects ordinary business practice and safeguards the creditor’s legitimate interests.

C.explanation: Option C is incorrect: the civil-law test looks at normal practice; deliberately ignoring custom and doing the bare minimum breaches §242.

D.explanation: Option D is incorrect because the good-faith duty applies automatically; parties are expected to comply without waiting for a court order.

questions.question: Why do the notes say good faith has two main jobs in civil-law contracts?

options.A: Claims that it only punishes fraudulent behaviour.
options.B: Claims that it works purely as a moral reminder with no legal effect.
options.C: Claims that it lets judges ignore the civil code.
options.D: Claims that it checks for unfair behaviour and fills gaps where the code is silent so deals stay balanced.

A.explanation: Option A is incorrect: although good faith catches outright fraud, the notes emphasise that it governs everyday performance as well.

B.explanation: Option B is incorrect because civil-law judges use the clause to impose legal duties; it is more than a moral nudge.

C.explanation: Option D is incorrect; the good-faith clause supplements the code rather than allowing judges to ignore it.

D.explanation: Correct option C: the notes describe two core roles—policing unfair behaviour and filling statutory gaps—so that agreements remain balanced.

questions.question: Which civil codes named in the notes include an express good-faith clause similar to Germany’s §242?

options.A: Claims that only the German BGB uses a good-faith rule.
options.B: Claims that only France keeps a good-faith clause today.
options.C: Claims that germany, the PRC, Taiwan, and Japan all embed good faith in their civil codes.
options.D: Claims that none of the modern Asian codes refer to good faith.

A.explanation: Option A is incorrect; the module lists several codes (PRC Art.7, Taiwan Art.148, Japan Art.1(2)) that echo Germany’s §242.

B.explanation: Option C is incorrect because the notes focus on these German and East Asian clauses rather than France alone.

C.explanation: Correct option B: Germany’s BGB, the PRC Civil Code, the Taiwanese Civil Code, and the Japanese Civil Code all write the good-faith duty directly into legislation.

D.explanation: Option D is incorrect; modern Asian codes explicitly refer to good faith.

questions.question: What does §307 BGB do when businesses use standard terms with consumers?

options.A: Claims that it strikes clauses that unfairly disadvantage the other party or hide their meaning.
options.B: Claims that it only checks spelling mistakes.
options.C: Claims that it replaces every clause with judge-made wording.
options.D: Claims that it automatically approves any written term.

A.explanation: Correct option D: §307 removes standard terms that significantly disadvantage the counterparty or hide their meaning, as the notes highlight.

B.explanation: Option B is incorrect because the review targets fairness and transparency, not spelling.

C.explanation: Option C is incorrect; courts delete abusive clauses but do not rewrite entire contracts.

D.explanation: Option A is incorrect; §307 BGB is a control mechanism, not a rubber stamp.

questions.question: Which example best shows an unfair standard term that §307 BGB would knock out?

options.A: Claims that a plain-language term that repeats the statutory warranty period.
options.B: Claims that a hidden clause that lets a seller avoid all responsibility for damage their delivery team causes inside the customer’s home.
options.C: Claims that a clause that restates the agreed price.
options.D: Claims that a term that gives the consumer a longer cooling-off period than the law requires.

A.explanation: Option B is incorrect; repeating a statutory warranty accurately keeps the parties on the legal baseline and is not unfair.

B.explanation: Correct option A: the notes give examples of hidden disclaimers being struck down because they eliminate core duties such as safe delivery, violating §307.

C.explanation: Option C is incorrect because restating the agreed price is neutral and fails to trigger §307.

D.explanation: Option D is incorrect; expanding the cooling-off period favours the consumer and therefore passes the fairness test.

questions.question: Why does §307 BGB insist on plain, understandable language in standard terms?

options.A: Claims that a company can hide the real meaning from customers.
options.B: Claims that spelling mistakes automatically cancel a contract.
options.C: Claims that only contracts shorter than one page are valid.
options.D: Claims that customers must understand their rights and duties before they agree.

A.explanation: Option A is incorrect; the whole point of §307 is to prevent concealment.

B.explanation: Option B is incorrect because civil-law judges worry about comprehension, not spelling errors.

C.explanation: Option D is incorrect; contract validity has nothing to do with the number of pages.

D.explanation: Correct option C: the provision insists that customers understand their rights and obligations before they commit to the agreement.

questions.question: Under §311 BGB, what duty arises once parties start serious contract talks?

options.A: Claims that no special duty arises until the contract is signed.
options.B: Claims that parties may freely give misleading facts to gain leverage.
options.C: Claims that each side must look after the other’s rights and avoid avoidable harm during negotiations.
options.D: Claims that they must sign a contract immediately.

A.explanation: Option A is incorrect; §311 BGB imposes duties during serious negotiations, not only after signature.

B.explanation: Option C is incorrect; supplying false information clashes with the duty of care that §311 establishes.

C.explanation: Correct option B: once talks take shape, each side must protect the other’s rights and avoid avoidable harm, as described in the notes.

D.explanation: Option D is incorrect because the duty is to act carefully, not to sign immediately.

questions.question: When can a third party owe negotiation duties under §311(3) BGB?

options.A: Claims that when the third party invites special trust and steers the talks.
options.B: Claims that only when the third party offers financing.
options.C: Claims that only if the third party is a government official.
options.D: Claims that never; duties bind only the people who sign the contract.

A.explanation: Correct option D: when a third party invites special trust and steers the discussions, §311(3) BGB imposes the same good-faith obligations on that party.

B.explanation: Option B is incorrect; simply offering finance is not enough under §311(3).

C.explanation: Option C is incorrect; public status is irrelevant—the issue is whether the party invites reliance.

D.explanation: Option A is incorrect; the notes explain that third parties can owe duties when they take control of negotiations.

questions.question: Which customer conversation best reflects good faith when explaining a tricky term?

options.A: Claims that the employee hands over dense legal citations and leaves.
options.B: Claims that the employee explains the term in everyday language, checks if the customer has questions, and gives a short written summary.
options.C: Claims that the employee says, ‘you signed it, so figure it out’ and walks away.
options.D: Claims that the employee hides the limitation so the sale goes through.

A.explanation: Option B is incorrect; dumping legal citations without guidance leaves the customer unable to make an informed choice.

B.explanation: Correct option A: the module recommends plain-language explanations, time for questions, and a short written recap to satisfy the civil-law clarity requirement.

C.explanation: Option C is incorrect because dismissing questions breaches the cooperative spirit of good faith.

D.explanation: Option D is incorrect; concealing important limits is precisely what §307 and §242 guard against.

questions.question: How should you explain good faith to a new hire according to the notes?

options.A: Claims that tell them it is an optional extra courtesy.
options.B: Claims that say it means always siding with the customer even if it breaks the deal.
options.C: Claims that describe it as a marketing slogan with no legal effect.
options.D: Claims that explain it means acting honestly, protecting the other side’s interests, and following normal practice even where the contract is silent.

A.explanation: Option A is incorrect; good faith is a statutory duty, not an optional courtesy.

B.explanation: Option B is incorrect; good faith balances both parties—civil law does not require self-sacrifice.

C.explanation: Option D is incorrect; calling good faith a marketing slogan ignores its legal effect.

D.explanation: Correct option C: the notes recommend an explanation that stresses honesty, protection of the counterparty’s interests, and respect for normal practice even when the contract is silent.

questions.question: What everyday check does the good-faith principle add to contract performance?

options.A: Claims that it removes every time limit from the contract.
options.B: Claims that it lets a party refuse to perform if profit is low.
options.C: Claims that it asks whether the promised behaviour is carried out in a way that keeps the other party safe and respected.
options.D: Claims that it allows ignoring local customs.

A.explanation: Option A is incorrect; contractual deadlines remain, the principle affects the manner of performance.

B.explanation: Option C is incorrect; poor profits do not justify breaching the duty.

C.explanation: Correct option B: good faith asks whether the promised behaviour keeps the other side safe and respected, which is the fairness ‘sense check’ discussed in the notes.

D.explanation: Option D is incorrect because the assessment expressly considers local custom.

questions.question: How did courts use good faith before the legislator wrote detailed rules on positive contract breach?

options.A: Claims that they used good faith to fill the gap and protect the buyer until the code was updated.
options.B: Claims that they insisted only tort law could apply.
options.C: Claims that they said only the contract text mattered.
options.D: Claims that they refused to help injured buyers.

A.explanation: Correct option D: good faith filled the gap until the codified rules on positive contract breach were enacted.

B.explanation: Option B is incorrect; judges did not force claimants into tort—they used contract-based good faith to protect them.

C.explanation: Option C is incorrect; judges looked beyond the literal text to evaluate delivery methods.

D.explanation: Option A is incorrect; courts used good faith to help injured buyers even before the Legislature intervened.

questions.question: Which scenario illustrates the ‘positive contract breach’ idea discussed in the notes?

options.A: Claims that a seller refuses to deliver anything at all.
options.B: Claims that a seller delivers the right machine but scratches the customer’s floor during delivery.
options.C: Claims that a buyer cancels before the contract exists.
options.D: Claims that a customer pays the price ahead of schedule.

A.explanation: Option B is incorrect; total non-delivery is dealt with by ordinary non-performance rules.

B.explanation: Correct option A: the notes describe this delivery scenario as a classic positive contract breach—performance occurs, but careless execution causes extra harm.

C.explanation: Option C is incorrect because the concept assumes a contract is in force.

D.explanation: Option D is incorrect; paying early is not a breach of the type discussed.

questions.question: Why was it useful for Germany to codify those good-faith duties into §§241(2), 280, and 311?

options.A: Claims that it removed all protective duties from the code.
options.B: Claims that it allowed courts to ignore good faith entirely.
options.C: Claims that it abolished consumer protection.
options.D: Claims that it gave clear text so everyone knows the duties still exist even when a judgment no longer cites good faith.

A.explanation: Option A is incorrect; codification preserved the protective duties.

B.explanation: Option B is incorrect; judges still apply the same ideas, now backed by statutory wording.

C.explanation: Option D is incorrect; consumer protection became clearer, not weaker.

D.explanation: Correct option C: putting the duties into §§241(2), 280, and 311 means everyone can see they still exist, even when judgments cite the sections instead of the general clause.

questions.question: Why do the notes say Asian codes like Japan and Korea still rely heavily on good-faith case law?

options.A: Claims that they reject German legal ideas.
options.B: Claims that they have no consumer disputes.
options.C: Claims that legislatures have not written every judge-made duty into the statute, so courts still cite good faith directly.
options.D: Claims that good faith is banned in those countries.

A.explanation: Option A is incorrect; far from rejecting German ideas, the notes show Japan and Korea follow them closely.

B.explanation: Option C is incorrect; consumer disputes certainly exist, which is why the doctrine matters.

C.explanation: Correct option B: because not every duty has been codified, courts in Japan and Korea still refer directly to the good-faith clause when dealing with new situations.

D.explanation: Option D is incorrect; good faith is expressly recognised in those codes.

questions.question: If you work in Taiwan and see a risk not covered in the contract text, what practical step do the notes hint at?

options.A: Claims that rely on the good-faith principle and explain how local courts have used it to fill that gap.
options.B: Claims that wait for the German parliament to amend its code first.
options.C: Claims that refuse to negotiate further.
options.D: Claims that assume no duty exists because it is not written down.

A.explanation: Correct option D: the notes suggest pointing to local good-faith case law to show how the courts close gaps.

B.explanation: Option B is incorrect; practitioners apply Taiwanese jurisprudence immediately and do not wait on German amendments.

C.explanation: Option C is incorrect; stopping negotiations wastes a ready-made tool.

D.explanation: Option A is incorrect; good faith fills contractual silence even without explicit wording.

questions.question: What is the key message about trusts that you should share with civil-law counterparts?

options.A: Claims that civil laws provide more detailed trust rules than common law.
options.B: Claims that most civil systems do not recognise split ownership, so discuss direct ownership instead.
options.C: Claims that trusts are mandatory in every civil-law contract.
options.D: Claims that trust law guarantees punitive damages.

A.explanation: Option B is incorrect; civil codes do not provide more detailed trust rules than the common law.

B.explanation: Correct option A: the module reminds common-law lawyers that civil-law systems usually refuse to divide legal and equitable ownership, so discussions must focus on direct title.

C.explanation: Option C is incorrect; trusts are not mandatory features of civil-law contracts.

D.explanation: Option D is incorrect; punitive damages are not tied to trust concepts here.

questions.question: How can you translate a common-law trust discussion for a civil-law colleague?

options.A: Claims that insist on using trustee and beneficiary labels only.
options.B: Claims that provide only English case citations.
options.C: Claims that say equity courts will sort it out.
options.D: Claims that describe who holds control and who enjoys the benefit without saying ownership is split.

A.explanation: Option A is incorrect; foreign labels such as ‘trustee’ may not convey the required meaning.

B.explanation: Option B is incorrect because citations alone rarely persuade without a civil-law translation.

C.explanation: Option D is incorrect; civil-law courts lack equity jurisdiction, so that reassurance would mislead.

D.explanation: Correct option C: describing who controls the property and who benefits mirrors the civil-law approach without implying split ownership.

questions.question: Why can mentioning ‘equity’ confuse a civil-law lawyer according to the notes?

options.A: Claims that equity is identical to good faith in every system.
options.B: Claims that they dislike fairness arguments.
options.C: Claims that equity is not a separate system in their codes, so the term has little meaning for them.
options.D: Claims that equity is illegal in civil-law countries.

A.explanation: Option A is incorrect; equity and good faith are distinct traditions.

B.explanation: Option C is incorrect; civil lawyers do care about fairness—they just express it through good faith and statutory duties.

C.explanation: Correct option B: civil-law codes do not have a separate equity system, so the word ‘equity’ offers little guidance to a civil lawyer.

D.explanation: Option D is incorrect; equity is not banned, it simply does not exist as a parallel system.

questions.question: How should you explain a fiduciary duty when talking to a civil-law partner?

options.A: Claims that frame it as a contractual or statutory duty to act loyally for the other person’s interests.
options.B: Claims that claim that beneficiaries own the property.
options.C: Claims that avoid discussing duties altogether.
options.D: Claims that say the court will enforce a trust deed exactly as in common law.

A.explanation: Correct option D: reframing fiduciary obligations as loyalty duties under contract or statute matches civil-law analysis.

B.explanation: Option B is incorrect because civil law refuses to split ownership in the way the common law does.

C.explanation: Option C is incorrect; avoiding the topic would leave the counterparty unprotected.

D.explanation: Option A is incorrect; trust deeds are not enforced verbatim in civil-law courts.

questions.question: What is the starting point for remedies in civil-law enforcement according to the notes?

options.A: Claims that damages automatically replace the obligation.
options.B: Claims that the promisee can demand the exact performance promised (enforced performance).
options.C: Claims that courts refuse to order performance.
options.D: Claims that only moral apologies are available.

A.explanation: Option B is incorrect; damages are secondary and come into play only if enforcement fails.

B.explanation: Correct option A: enforced performance is the presumptive remedy, as the notes explain.

C.explanation: Option C is incorrect; civil courts routinely order performance.

D.explanation: Option D is incorrect; apologies are not the focus of civil-law enforcement.

questions.question: How do the notes contrast enforced performance with the common-law idea of ‘specific performance’?

options.A: Claims that both treat damages as the default.
options.B: Claims that civil systems rarely enforce promises.
options.C: Claims that civil law forbids damages altogether.
options.D: Claims that enforced performance is the normal rule in civil law, while ‘specific performance’ is exceptional in the common law.

A.explanation: Option A is incorrect; civil law does not treat damages as the primary response.

B.explanation: Option B is incorrect; civil courts enforce promises regularly.

C.explanation: Option D is incorrect; damages remain available as part of the secondary rights package.

D.explanation: Correct option C: the module stresses that enforced performance is ‘normal’ in civil law, whereas the common-law remedy of specific performance is exceptional.

questions.question: What does the maxim ‘pacta sunt servanda’ explain in this module?

options.A: Claims that deals can be rewritten at will.
options.B: Claims that only oral promises matter.
options.C: Claims that promises are binding, so the agreed performance must be delivered as written.
options.D: Claims that contracts expire after 30 days.

A.explanation: Option A is incorrect; the maxim enforces original promises, it does not permit rewriting them.

B.explanation: Option C is incorrect; the maxim applies to written and oral contracts alike.

C.explanation: Correct option B: ‘pacta sunt servanda’—agreements must be kept—explains why enforced performance is the first step.

D.explanation: Option D is incorrect; it says nothing about automatic expiry dates.

questions.question: What order of steps do the notes suggest before moving to secondary rights?

options.A: Claims that request performance, allow the grace period unless an exception applies, then switch to secondary rights if the debtor still fails.
options.B: Claims that terminate first, then ask for performance later.
options.C: Claims that ignore the delay if the loss is small.
options.D: Claims that claim damages immediately without warning.

A.explanation: Correct option D: demand performance, grant a Nachfrist unless an exception applies, then choose secondary rights if the debtor still fails.

B.explanation: Option B is incorrect; termination is a later step after enforcement has failed.

C.explanation: Option C is incorrect; ignoring delays undermines the enforcement scheme.

D.explanation: Option A is incorrect; the notes say you should not jump straight to damages.

questions.question: Why must the promisee usually give a grace period (Nachfrist)?

options.A: Claims that punish the creditor.
options.B: Claims that give the debtor a fair second chance to deliver the promised item before harsher remedies start.
options.C: Claims that courts dislike on-time delivery.
options.D: Claims that the contract automatically cancels.

A.explanation: Option B is incorrect; the debtor—not the creditor—benefits from the extra time.

B.explanation: Correct option A: the grace period gives the debtor a final chance to comply before the creditor switches remedies.

C.explanation: Option C is incorrect; courts still value timely performance.

D.explanation: Option D is incorrect; the contract does not dissolve automatically just because a grace period exists.

questions.question: What should you communicate during a Nachfrist letter?

options.A: Claims that only complain without setting a date.
options.B: Claims that the model rests on state that you will never accept the goods.
options.C: Claims that promise to forgive every delay.
options.D: Claims that set a reasonable extra deadline and warn that other remedies follow if it passes.

A.explanation: Option A is incorrect; a Nachfrist letter needs a clear additional deadline.

B.explanation: Option B is incorrect; refusing the goods contradicts the purpose of enforced performance.

C.explanation: Option D is incorrect; promising forgiveness removes the pressure to perform.

D.explanation: Correct option C: the notes recommend setting a reasonable extra period and warning that other remedies will follow if it lapses.

questions.question: When may you skip the grace period under the civil-law rules described in the notes?

options.A: Claims that whenever you are annoyed.
options.B: Claims that whenever damages would be higher.
options.C: Claims that when the debtor refuses, the timing is critical, or performance is impossible from the start.
options.D: Claims that only after a court trial.

A.explanation: Option A is incorrect; personal annoyance is not a recognised exception.

B.explanation: Option C is incorrect; the size of potential damages is irrelevant to the Nachfrist requirement.

C.explanation: Correct option B: the module lists debtor refusal, time-critical obligations, and impossibility as situations where the grace period can be skipped.

D.explanation: Option D is incorrect; you do not need to wait for a trial to rely on the exceptions.

questions.question: What documentation step should you take if you rely on a grace-period exception?

options.A: Claims that record why the exception applies so you can justify switching to secondary rights.
options.B: Claims that delete all emails.
options.C: Claims that send a handwritten apology.
options.D: Claims that no documentation is needed.

A.explanation: Correct option D: documenting why an exception applies supports the shift to secondary rights.

B.explanation: Option B is incorrect; deleting emails destroys evidence of compliance.

C.explanation: Option C is incorrect; apologies do not prove legal grounds.

D.explanation: Option A is incorrect; contemporaneous notes help justify your decision later.

questions.question: What can the promisee claim while the grace period is running?

options.A: Claims that punitive damages.
options.B: Claims that damages for delay if the late delivery causes loss, even while still demanding performance.
options.C: Claims that criminal fines.
options.D: Claims that nothing until a court judgment.

A.explanation: Option B is incorrect; punitive damages do not feature in this civil-law framework.

B.explanation: Correct option A: the notes explain you can claim damages for delay while still demanding performance during the Nachfrist period.

C.explanation: Option C is incorrect; criminal fines are not part of contractual enforcement.

D.explanation: Option D is incorrect; the promisee need not wait for judgment to pursue delay losses.

questions.question: What happens if the debtor still fails after the grace period ends?

options.A: Claims that the promisee has no options left.
options.B: Claims that the contract automatically disappears without remedies.
options.C: Claims that only the debtor may choose the remedy.
options.D: Claims that the promisee can switch to secondary rights such as damages or rescission.

A.explanation: Option A is incorrect; additional remedies open up once Nachfrist ends.

B.explanation: Option B is incorrect; the contract does not vanish without action.

C.explanation: Option D is incorrect; the creditor, not the debtor, chooses among the secondary rights.

D.explanation: Correct option C: after the grace period the creditor may rescind or demand damages, as set out in the notes.

questions.question: How do the notes describe ‘secondary rights’?

options.A: Claims that additional promises the debtor receives.
options.B: Claims that criminal sanctions for fraud.
options.C: Claims that remedies like damages or withdrawal that replace the original performance when the debtor fails.
options.D: Claims that tax adjustments.

A.explanation: Option A is incorrect; secondary rights belong to the promisee.

B.explanation: Option C is incorrect; criminal sanctions are outside the civil-law remedies discussed.

C.explanation: Correct option B: the notes define secondary rights as remedies like damages or withdrawal that step in when performance fails.

D.explanation: Option D is incorrect; taxes have nothing to do with this concept.

questions.question: Which situation shows a creditor choosing a secondary right sensibly?

options.A: Claims that after the Nachfrist expires, they cancel the contract and claim compensation for buying a replacement.
options.B: Claims that they demand performance but never follow up.
options.C: Claims that they ignore legal process and hire vigilantes.
options.D: Claims that they keep waiting forever despite repeated failures.

A.explanation: Correct option D: cancelling and claiming cover costs after Nachfrist mirrors the textbook use of secondary rights.

B.explanation: Option B is incorrect; failing to follow up undermines your position.

C.explanation: Option C is incorrect; vigilante tactics are unlawful.

D.explanation: Option A is incorrect; waiting forever defeats the enforcement process.

questions.question: What does §275 BGB do when performance becomes impossible?

options.A: Claims that it increases the price automatically.
options.B: Claims that it removes the right to demand performance to the extent it cannot be done.
options.C: Claims that it forces the debtor to perform anyway.
options.D: Claims that it jails the debtor.

A.explanation: Option B is incorrect; the statute says nothing about price adjustments.

B.explanation: Correct option A: §275 removes the obligation to perform where fulfilment is impossible.

C.explanation: Option C is incorrect; impossible acts cannot be forced.

D.explanation: Option D is incorrect because §275 has no criminal element.

questions.question: If the debtor is responsible for the impossibility described in §275, what do the notes say happens?

options.A: Claims that the debtor is free from all consequences.
options.B: Claims that the creditor must pay damages instead.
options.C: Claims that the contract turns into a gift.
options.D: Claims that the debtor still owes damages even though the performance duty is gone.

A.explanation: Option A is incorrect; a culpable debtor still faces liability.

B.explanation: Option B is incorrect; the creditor does not owe damages— they are the party harmed.

C.explanation: Option D is incorrect; the contract does not become a gift.

D.explanation: Correct option C: even when performance ends, the debtor who caused the impossibility must compensate the creditor for the loss.

questions.question: Which example matches an impossibility under §275?

options.A: Claims that a seller forgets to ship the goods but still has them in stock.
options.B: Claims that goods are in stock but delivery is expensive.
options.C: Claims that a unique artwork promised in the contract burns in a fire with no replacement available.
options.D: Claims that the buyer changes their mind.

A.explanation: Option A is incorrect; stock on hand means performance remains possible.

B.explanation: Option C is incorrect; high cost alone is not impossibility.

C.explanation: Correct option B: destruction of the unique artwork makes performance objectively impossible under §275.

D.explanation: Option D is incorrect; a buyer’s change of mind is not impossibility.

questions.question: What practical step should a project manager take if performance may become impossible?

options.A: Claims that communicate early, record the facts, and assess whether §275 removes the duty while damages still apply.
options.B: Claims that destroy any evidence of the problem.
options.C: Claims that demand punitive damages immediately.
options.D: Claims that say nothing and hope it resolves itself.

A.explanation: Correct option D: the notes advise early communication, documentation, and analysis of whether §275 applies alongside damages.

B.explanation: Option B is incorrect; destroying evidence undermines any later defence.

C.explanation: Option C is incorrect; punitive damages are not the focus here.

D.explanation: Option A is incorrect; silence can breach the good-faith duty to cooperate.

questions.question: How should you brief your team about enforced performance expectations?

options.A: Claims that tell them obligations are optional.
options.B: Claims that explain that delivering exactly what was promised is the default and damages come later.
options.C: Claims that focus only on penalties.
options.D: Claims that say courts rarely care about performance.

A.explanation: Option B is incorrect; obligations are mandatory.

B.explanation: Correct option A: briefing teams that exact performance is expected (with damages only later) mirrors the civil-law perspective.

C.explanation: Option C is incorrect; the message is about reliable delivery, not just punishment.

D.explanation: Option D is incorrect; courts do care deeply about performance.

questions.question: What monitoring step helps you stay within good faith during contract performance?

options.A: Claims that avoid documenting decisions so there is no paper trail.
options.B: Claims that change contract terms unilaterally.
options.C: Claims that review problems only after a dispute begins.
options.D: Claims that track how each action affects the other party and adjust to keep their interests protected.

A.explanation: Option A is incorrect; documentation proves you acted in good faith.

B.explanation: Option B is incorrect; unilateral changes breach the duty.

C.explanation: Option D is incorrect; waiting for a dispute ignores early warning signs.

D.explanation: Correct option C: monitoring the impact on the counterparty and adjusting accordingly keeps performance within the good-faith standard.

questions.question: How can you align with a civil-law counterpart during negotiations?

options.A: Claims that insist on trust terminology.
options.B: Claims that refuse to mention local law.
options.C: Claims that frame proposals in terms of good faith duties and enforced performance expectations.
options.D: Claims that threaten to sue in an equity court.

A.explanation: Option A is incorrect; trust terminology rarely translates for civil-law partners.

B.explanation: Option C is incorrect; refusing to discuss local law alienates the counterpart.

C.explanation: Correct option B: presenting proposals in terms of good faith and enforced performance shows you understand their legal framework.

D.explanation: Option D is incorrect; threatening equity remedies is meaningless in civil law.

questions.question: What should you do when a dispute involves concepts like trusts that civil-law courts do not use?

options.A: Claims that translate the issue into direct ownership and contractual duties that the civil code recognises.
options.B: Claims that demand that the court adopt trust language.
options.C: Claims that abandon legal reasoning entirely.
options.D: Claims that argue only English case law.

A.explanation: Correct option D: translating the issue into direct ownership and contractual duties keeps the dispute within the civil code.

B.explanation: Option B is incorrect; forcing trust language confuses the court.

C.explanation: Option C is incorrect; you still need to reason legally, but in local terms.

D.explanation: Option A is incorrect; foreign case law alone rarely persuades a civil-law forum.

questions.question: What internal control helps ensure standard terms stay compliant with §307?

options.A: Claims that delete the terms after signing.
options.B: Claims that keep a checklist that tests each clause for clarity and fairness.
options.C: Claims that hide extra conditions in email footers.
options.D: Claims that tell staff to rely on verbal promises only.

A.explanation: Option B is incorrect; deleting terms destroys proof of compliance.

B.explanation: Correct option A: the module recommends a checklist to ensure each clause remains clear and fair under §307.

C.explanation: Option C is incorrect; hiding conditions breaches the transparency requirement.

D.explanation: Option D is incorrect; relying only on verbal assurances undermines reviewability.
